title: Leadership and commitment
content: Top management must demonstrate leadership and commitment to the information security management system (ISMS) by assigning roles, ensuring resources, and integrating ISMS requirements into business processes.

title: Information security roles & responsibilities
content: Organizations must define, allocate, and communicate information security responsibilities across roles and ensure that individuals understand their duties and necessary competence.

title: Competence and awareness
content: Employees and contractors must receive training and maintain competence in information security relevant to their role; awareness programs should reduce human risk vectors.

title: Asset management overview
content: Identify and maintain an inventory of information assets, classify assets by sensitivity, and assign asset owners responsible for protection measures.

title: Access control policy
content: Access to systems and data must follow a formal access control policy based on the principle of least privilege and need-to-know; access reviews should be periodic.

title: Technical vulnerability and patch management
content: Organizations must identify, assess, and remediate technical vulnerabilities promptly, with a documented patch management and change control process for critical systems.

title: Event logging and monitoring
content: Implement logging and monitoring to detect security events; retain logs for investigations and tie detection to incident response playbooks.

title: Reporting information security events
content: Define incident reporting channels and responsibilities; incidents must be recorded, classified, and escalated according to impact and regulatory obligations.

title: AI management system scope and context
content: Establish an AI management system scope aligned with organizational objectives, defining AI use-cases, stakeholders, data sources, and governance boundaries for risk management.

title: Roles and responsibilities for AI governance
content: Assign roles for AI lifecycle oversight (owners, data stewards, model stewards), and ensure accountability for model development, deployment, and monitoring.

title: AI risk assessment
content: Perform risk assessments specific to AI systems that consider data bias, model misuse, accuracy, explainability, and potential safety impacts; document mitigations.

title: Model validation and testing
content: Model validation must include performance, fairness, and robustness tests; maintain test datasets and versioned validation reports prior to production deployment.

title: Control environment & organization
content: Design and maintain a control environment with documented responsibilities, code of conduct, and governance that support security and privacy objectives.

title: Change management controls
content: Change management must ensure authorized, tested, and documented changes with rollback plans and segregation of duties to prevent unauthorized production changes.

title: High-risk AI systems criteria
content: The EU AI Act classifies certain AI systems as high-risk (e.g., safety-critical, HR, law enforcement); these require stricter governance, conformity assessments, and documentation.

title: Transparency obligations
content: Operators must provide meaningful information on system capabilities and limitations; where applicable, provide user-facing transparency and documentation on intended use.

title: Access Control family (AC)
content: Access Control family requires mechanisms for identification, authentication, authorization, session management, and least privilege enforcement across systems.

title: Risk assessment family (RA)
content: Risk assessment processes must categorize information systems, identify threats and vulnerabilities, and prioritize mitigations based on impact and likelihood.

title: Injection prevention guidance
content: Validate and sanitize inputs, use parameterized queries, and enforce strict parsing to prevent injection vulnerabilities (SQL, command, template injections).

title: AI-specific threat modeling patterns
content: Consider prompt injection, model inversion, data poisoning, and adversarial inputs; include mitigations in the SDLC and runtime monitoring for anomalies.

title: User access provisioning and deprovisioning
content: Implement formal user provisioning/deprovisioning processes, including timely revocation on role change or termination and periodic access certification.

title: Cryptographic controls
content: Use well-vetted cryptographic algorithms and key lifecycle management: generation, distribution, rotation, storage, and retirement with documented policies.

title: Operational monitoring of AI systems
content: Monitor AI models in production for performance drift, data distribution changes, and safety violations; trigger retraining or mitigation when thresholds are breached.

title: Data quality & governance requirements
content: High-risk AI systems must ensure data quality, provenance, and documentation of datasets used for training and testing to reduce bias and maintain traceability.

title: System operations and availability
content: Establish operational procedures, capacity planning, backups and disaster recovery to maintain system availability and meet defined SLA commitments.

title: System change monitoring
content: Monitor and log system changes; correlate change events with approvals and deployments to ensure traceability and detect unauthorized changes.

title: Controlled unclassified information (CUI) protections
content: Protect sensitive but unclassified information with controls for access, encryption, guarding against exfiltration, and secure handling across supply chains.

title: Risk-based prioritization
content: Use evidence-driven risk scoring to prioritize fixes: impact, exploitability, exposure, and asset criticality drive remediation order and resource allocation.

title: Physical and environmental security
content: Protect physical assets and facilities through controlled entry, environmental protections, and asset location management to prevent unauthorized access and damage.

title: Continual improvement of AI systems
content: Implement continual improvement processes for AI systems: lessons learned from incidents, model performance reviews, and updates to governance based on outcomes.
